abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Economic Recovery Loan (ERL) to Panama,
            Overall performance is highly satisfactory and performance
            of both bank and borrower is satisfactory. Lessons learned
            are: the ultimate success of the ERL demonstrates that under
            certain circumstances, the Bank can justify the pursuit of a
            "high risk-high reward" strategy; Design of reform
            programs should aim for simplicity and compactness.
            Experience indicates that where there is a need for a reform
            agenda as broad and complex as the ERL's, it may be
            preferable to develop several sequential adjustment
            operations tailored to a borrower's implementation
            capacity rather than one large operation;  This operation
            confirms once again the desirability of local ownership of
            reform programs being shared by the government and key
            groups in civil society; the ERL demonstrates once again the
            desirability of having the passage of satisfactory
            legislation as conditions for Board presentation and not as
            tranche conditions; and Public expenditure reform should be
            derived from considerations of the appropriate role of
            government following a public sector expenditure review, and
            identification of a systematic set of actions that would
            ensure achievement of target.

5082173.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The loan will support the
            Government's Economic Recovery Program, which is
            designed to:  (i) encourage sustained economic growth by
            raising public investment, and by increasing private sector
            efficiency through trade and tax reforms; and (ii) help
            stabilize public sector finances by reducing the public wage
            bill and eliminating the social security system's cash
            deficit in no more than 10 years.
